guillemot.definition: One of several northern sea birds, allied to the auks. They have short legs, placed far back, and are expert divers and swimmers

guilloche.definition: An ornament in the form of two or more bands or strings twisted over each other in a continued series, leaving circular openings which are filled with round ornaments
In ornamental art, any pattern made by interlacing curved lines

guillotine.definition: A machine for beheading a person by one stroke of a heavy ax or blade, which slides in vertical guides, is raised by a cord, and let fall upon the neck of the victim
Any machine or instrument for cutting or shearing, resembling in its action a guillotine

guilt.definition: The criminality and consequent exposure to punishment resulting from willful disobedience of law, or from morally wrong action; the state of one who has broken a moral or political law; crime; criminality; offense against right
Exposure to any legal penalty or forfeiture
A feeling of regret or remorse for having committed some improper act; a recognition of one's own responsibility for doing something wrong

guilt-ridden.definition: mentally anguished due to feelings of guilt{3}

guilt-sick.definition: Made sick by consciousness of guilt

guiltiness.definition: The quality or state of being guilty

guilty.definition: Having incurred guilt; criminal; morally delinquent; wicked; chargeable with, or responsible for, something censurable; justly exposed to penalty; -- used with of, and usually followed by the crime, sometimes by the punishment; as, guilty of murder
Evincing or indicating guilt; involving guilt; as, a guilty look; a guilty act; a guilty feeling

guimpe.definition: A kind of short blouse or chemisette, worn under a low-necked dress such as a jumper or pinafore
a piece of starched cloth covering the shoulders of a nun's habit

guinea.definition: A district on the west coast of Africa (formerly noted for its export of gold and slaves) after which the Guinea fowl, Guinea grass, Guinea peach, etc., are named
A gold coin of England current for twenty-one shillings sterling, or about five dollars, but not coined since the issue of sovereigns in 1817

guinea pig.definition: A small Brazilian rodent (Cavia porcellus or Cavia cobaya), about seven inches in length and usually of a white color, with spots of orange and black.  Called also cavy.  It is the domesticated form of the wild cavy, often kept as a pet and used commonly as an experimental animal in laboratory research
Any animal or person used in an experiment; -- also applied to people who are unwillingly or unknowingly subjected by authorities to policies or procedures which might cause bodily or mental harm

guinea-pig director.definition: A director (usually one holding a number of directorships) who serves merely or mainly for the fee (in England, often a guinea) paid for attendance

guinean.definition: of or pertaining to Guinea{1}; as, Guinean borders
of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Guinea{1}; as, Guinean soldiers
a native or inhabitant of Guinea{1}

guinness.definition: a kind of bitter stout, also called Guiness' stout; as, a glass of Guinness

guipure.definition: A term used for lace of different kinds; most properly for a lace of large pattern and heavy material which has no ground or mesh, but has the pattern held together by connecting threads called bars or brides

guise.definition: Customary way of speaking or acting; custom; fashion; manner; behavior; mien; mode; practice; -- often used formerly in such phrases as: at his own guise; that is, in his own fashion, to suit himself
External appearance in manner or dress; appropriate indication or expression; garb; shape
Cover; cloak; as, under the guise of patriotism

guiser.definition: A person in disguise; a masker; a mummer

guitar.definition: A stringed instrument of music resembling the lute or the violin, but larger, and having six strings, three of silk covered with silver wire, and three of catgut, -- played upon with the fingers

guitarfish.definition: A primitive tropical bottom-dwelling ray of the family Rhinobatidae with a guitar-shaped body

guitarist.definition: a musician who plays the guitar

guitguit.definition: One of several species of small tropical American birds of the family Cœrebidæ, allied to the creepers; -- called also quit. See Quit

gulae.definition: The upper front of the neck, next to the chin; the upper throat
A capping molding. Same as Cymatium

gular.definition: Pertaining to the gula or throat; as, gular plates. See Illust. of Bird, and Bowfin

gulch.definition: A ravine, or part of the deep bed of a torrent when dry; a gully
To swallow greedily; to gulp down

gule.definition: To give the color of gules to

gules.definition: The tincture red, indicated in seals and engraved figures of escutcheons by parallel vertical lines. Hence, used poetically for a red color or that which is red

gulf.definition: A hollow place in the earth; an abyss; a deep chasm or basin,
That which swallows irretrievably; a whirlpool; a sucking eddy
A portion of an ocean or sea extending into the land; a partially land-locked sea; as, the Gulf of Mexico
A large deposit of ore in a lode

gulfweed.definition: A brown seaweed (Sargassum bacciferum) with rounded bladders forming dense floating masses in tropical Atlantic waters as in the Sargasso Sea

gulgul.definition: A cement made in India from sea shells, pulverized and mixed with oil, and spread over a ship's bottom, to prevent the boring of worms

gull.definition: To deceive; to cheat; to mislead; to trick; to defraud
A cheating or cheat; trick; fraud
One of many species of long-winged sea birds of the genus Larus and allied genera

gullery.definition: An act, or the practice, of gulling; trickery; fraud

gullet.definition: The tube by which food and drink are carried from the pharynx to the stomach; the esophagus
Something shaped like the food passage, or performing similar functions

gulleting.definition: A system of excavating by means of gullets or channels

gullible.definition: Easily gulled; that may be duped

gully.definition: A channel or hollow worn in the earth by a current of water; a short deep portion of a torrent's bed when dry
A grooved iron rail or tram plate
To wear into a gully or into gullies

gulp.definition: To swallow eagerly, or in large draughts; to swallow up; to take down at one swallow
The act of taking a large mouthful; a swallow, or as much as is awallowed at once

guly.definition: Of or pertaining to gules; red

gum.definition: The dense tissues which invest the teeth, and cover the adjacent parts of the jaws
To deepen and enlarge the spaces between the teeth of (a worn saw). See Gummer

A vegetable secretion of many trees or plants that hardens when it exudes, but is soluble in water; as, gum arabic; gum tragacanth; the gum of the cherry tree. Also, with less propriety, exudations that are not soluble in water; as, gum copal and gum sandarac, which are really resins
A hive made of a section of a hollow gum tree; hence, any roughly made hive; also, a vessel or bin made of a hollow log
To smear with gum; to close with gum; to unite or stiffen by gum or a gumlike substance; to make sticky with a gumlike substance
To chew with the gums, rather than with the teeth
To exude or form gum; to become gummy

gum tree.definition: Any tree that exudes a gum,

gum-lac.definition: an inferior lac produced by lac insects in Madagascar

gumball.definition: A piece of chewing gum in the shape of a ball, usually covered with a colored glaze of sugar.  They are often sold in a small, special-purpose coin-operated vending machine called a gumball machine

gumbo.definition: A soup thickened with the mucilaginous pods of the okra; okra soup
The okra plant or its pods

gumbo-limbo.definition: A tropical American tree (Bursera simaruba) yielding a reddish resin used in cements and varnishes

gumboil.definition: A small suppurating inflamed spot on the gum

gumma.definition: A kind of soft tumor, usually of syphilitic origin

gummer.definition: A punch-cutting tool, or machine for deepening and enlarging the spaces between the teeth of a worn saw

gumminess.definition: The state or quality of being gummy; viscousness

gummite.definition: A yellow amorphous mineral, essentially a hydrated oxide of uranium derived from the alteration of uraninite

gummosity.definition: Gumminess; a viscous or adhesive quality or nature

gummous.definition: Gumlike, or composed of gum; gummy
Of or pertaining to a gumma

gummy.definition: Consisting of gum; viscous; adhesive; producing or containing gum; covered with gum or a substance resembling gum

gumshield.definition: A piece of athletic equipment that protects an athlete's mouth

gumshoe.definition: A shoe made of rubber, as a rubber overshoe

gumweed.definition: any of various Western American plants of the genus Grindelia having resinous leaves and stems formerly used medicinally; often poisonous to livestock

gumwood.definition: wood or lumber from any of various gum trees especially the sweet gum

gun.definition: A weapon which throws or propels a missile to a distance; any firearm or instrument for throwing projectiles, consisting of a tube or barrel closed at one end, in which the projectile is placed, with an explosive charge (such as guncotton or gunpowder) behind, which is ignited by various means. Pistols, rifles, carbines, muskets, and fowling pieces are smaller guns, for hand use, and are called small arms.  Larger guns are called cannon, ordnance, fieldpieces, carronades, howitzers, etc. See these terms in the Vocabulary
A piece of heavy ordnance; in a restricted sense, a cannon
To practice fowling or hunting small game; -- chiefly in participial form; as, to go gunning

gun for.definition: To pursue with the intent to kill
To make an effort to harm someone, especially with determination; -- also used humorously

guna.definition: In Sanskrit grammar, a lengthening of the simple vowels a, i, e, by prefixing an a element. The term is sometimes used to denote the same vowel change in other languages

gunboat.definition: A vessel of light draught, carrying one or more guns, used for operations in shallow waters
Any small naval vessel carrying mounted guns

gunflint.definition: A sharpened flint for the lock of a gun, to ignite the charge. It was in common use before the introduction of percussion caps

gunk.definition: any thick gooey and messy substance

gunlock.definition: The mechanism of a gun for producing the discharge. See Lock

gunnage.definition: The number of guns carried by a ship of war

gunnel.definition: A small, eel-shaped, marine fish of the genus Murænoides; esp., M. gunnellus of Europe and America; -- called also gunnel fish, butterfish, rock eel

gunner.definition: One who works a gun or cannon, whether on land, sea, or in the air; a cannoneer
A warrant officer in the navy having charge of the ordnance on a vessel
The great northern diver or loon. See Loon

gunnery.definition: That branch of military science which comprehends the theory of projectiles, and the manner of constructing and using ordnance

gunnie.definition: Space left by the removal of ore

gunning.definition: The act or practice of hunting or shooting game with a gun

gunny.definition: A strong, coarse kind of sacking, made from the fibers (called jute) of two plants of the genus Corchorus (C. olitorius and C. capsularis), of India. The fiber is also used in the manufacture of cordage

gunplay.definition: An instance of the firing of small arms with the intent to kill or frighten

gunpoint.definition: The muzzle's direction; as, he held me up at gunpoint
The open discharging end of a gun

gunpowder.definition: A black, granular, explosive substance, consisting of an intimate mechanical mixture of saltpeter, charcoal, and sulphur. It is used in gunnery and blasting

gunreach.definition: The reach or distance to which a gun will shoot; gunshot

gunroom.definition: An apartment on the after end of the lower gun deck of a ship of war, usually occupied as a messroom by the commissioned officers, except the captain; -- called wardroom in the United States navy

gunshot.definition: Act of firing a gun; a shot
The distance to which shot can be thrown from a gun, so as to be effective; the reach or range of a gun
Made by the shot of a gun; as, a gunshot wound

gunsight.definition: A sight{9} attached to a gun, used for aiming it at the target.  Same as sight{9}

gunsmith.definition: One whose occupation is to make or repair small firearms; an armorer

gunsmithery.definition: The art or business of a gunsmith

gunstick.definition: A stick to ram down the charge of a musket, etc.; a rammer or ramrod

gunstock.definition: The stock or wood to which the barrel of a hand gun is fastened

gunstone.definition: A cannon ball; -- so called because originally made of stone

gunter rig.definition: A topmast arranged with metal bands so that it will readily slide up and down the lower mast

gunter's chain.definition: The chain ordinarily used in measuring land. See Chain, n., 4, and Gunter's scale

gunter's line.definition: A logarithmic line on Gunter's scale, used for performing the multiplication and division of numbers mechanically by the dividers; -- called also line of lines, and line of numbers

gunter's quadrant.definition: A thin quadrant, made of brass, wood, etc., showing a stereographic projection on the plane of the equator. By it are found the hour of the day, the sun's azimuth, the altitude of objects in degrees, etc. See Gunter's scale

gunter's scale.definition: A scale invented by the Rev. Edmund Gunter (1581-1626), a professor of astronomy at Gresham College, London, who invented also Gunter's chain, and Gunter's quadrant

gunwale.definition: The upper edge of a vessel's or boat's side; the uppermost wale of a ship (not including the bulwarks); or that piece of timber which reaches on either side from the quarter-deck to the forecastle, being the uppermost bend, which finishes the upper works of the hull

guppy.definition: A small freshwater fish of South America and West Indies (Lebistes reticulatus or Poecilia reticulata, originaly called Gerardinus guppyi), often kept in aquariums; also called rainbow fish

gurgle.definition: To run or flow in a broken, irregular, noisy current, as water from a bottle, or a small stream among pebbles or stones
The act of gurgling; a broken, bubbling noise

gurglet.definition: A porous earthen jar for cooling water by evaporation

gurjun.definition: A thin balsam or wood oil derived from the Diptcrocarpus lævis, an East Indian tree. It is used in medicine, and as a substitute for linseed oil in the coarser kinds of paint

gurl.definition: A young person of either sex.  See Girl

gurlet.definition: A pickax with one sharp point and one cutting edge

gurnard.definition: One ofseveral European marine fishes, of the genus Trigla and allied genera, having a large and spiny head, with mailed cheeks. Some of the species are highly esteemed for food. The name is sometimes applied to the American sea robins

gurry.definition: An alvine evacuation; also, refuse matter

gurt.definition: A gutter or channel for water, hewn out of the bottom of a working drift

gush.definition: To issue with violence and rapidity, as a fluid; to rush forth as a fluid from confinement; to flow copiously
To make a sentimental or untimely exhibition of affection; to display enthusiasm in a silly, demonstrative manner

A sudden and violent issue of a fluid from an inclosed plase; an emission of a liquid in a large quantity, and with force; the fluid thus emitted; a rapid outpouring of anything; as, a gush of song from a bird
A sentimental exhibition of affection or enthusiasm, etc.; effusive display of sentiment

gushing.definition: Rushing forth with violence, as a fluid; flowing copiously; as, gushing waters
Emitting copiously, as tears or words; weakly and unreservedly demonstrative in matters of affection; sentimental

gushy.definition: extravagantly demonstrative; gushing{2}; as, to write unrestrained and gushy poetry

gusset.definition: A small piece of cloth inserted in a garment, for the purpose of strengthening some part or giving it a tapering enlargement
Anything resembling a gusset in a garment
An abatement or mark of dishonor in a coat of arms, resembling a gusset

gusseted.definition: provided or reinforced with gussets.  Opposite of ungusseted

gussied.definition: dressed up; well-dressed; as, all gussied up in sequins and feathers

gust.definition: A sudden squall; a violent blast of wind; a sudden and brief rushing or driving of the wind
A sudden violent burst of passion
The sense or pleasure of tasting; relish; gusto
Gratification of any kind, particularly that which is exquisitely relished; enjoyment
To taste; to have a relish for

gustable.definition: Pleasant to the taste; toothsome; savory

gustatory.definition: Pertaining to, or subservient to, the sense of taste; as, the gustatory nerve which supplies the front of the tongue

gusto.definition: Nice or keen appreciation or enjoyment; relish; taste; fancy; as, he ate it with gusto

gustoso.definition: Tasteful; in a tasteful, agreeable manner

gusty.definition: Subject to, or characterized by, gusts or squalls; windy; stormy; tempestuous

gut.definition: A narrow passage of water; as, the Gut of Canso
An intenstine; a bowel; the whole alimentary canal; the enteron; (pl.) bowels; entrails
One of the prepared entrails of an animal, esp. of a sheep, used for various purposes. See Catgut
The sac of silk taken from a silkworm (when ready to spin its cocoon), for the purpose of drawing it out into a thread. This, when dry, is exceedingly strong, and is used as the snood of a fish line
To take out the bowels from; to eviscerate
To plunder of contents; to destroy or remove the interior or contents of; as, a mob gutted the house

gutless.definition: lacking courage or vitality; as, he was a yellow gutless worm.  Opposite of gutsy

gutsy.definition: marked by courage and determination in the face of difficulties or danger
rough or plain; not sophisticated or refined; earthy.  Opposite of sophisticated, or refined

gutta-percha.definition: A concrete juice produced by various trees found in the Malayan archipelago, especially by the Isonandra Gutta, syn. Dichopsis Gutta.  It becomes soft, and unpressible at the tamperature of boiling water, and, on cooling, retains its new shape. It dissolves in oils and ethers, but not in water. In many of its properties it resembles caoutchouc, and it is extensively used for many economical purposes. The Mimusops globosa of Guiana also yields this material

guttae.definition: One of a series of ornaments, in the form of a frustum of a cone, attached to the lower part of the triglyphs, and also to the lower faces of the mutules, in the Doric order; -- called also campana, and drop

guttate.definition: Spotted, as if discolored by drops

guttated.definition: Besprinkled with drops, or droplike spots

guttatrap.definition: The inspissated juice of a tree of the genus Artocarpus (A. incisa, or breadfruit tree), sometimes used in making birdlime, on account of its glutinous quality

gutter.definition: A channel at the eaves of a roof for conveying away the rain; an eaves channel; an eaves trough
A small channel at the roadside or elsewhere, to lead off surface water
Any narrow channel or groove; as, a gutter formed by erosion in the vent of a gun from repeated firing

Either of two sunken channels at either side of the bowling alley, leading directly to the sunken pit behind the pins.  Balls not thrown accurately at the pins will drop into such a channel bypassing the pins, and resulting in a score of zero for that bowl
To cut or form into small longitudinal hollows; to channel
To supply with a gutter or gutters
To become channeled, as a candle when the flame flares in the wind

gutter ball.definition: A bowl in which the ball falls into the gutter{4}, resulting in a score of zero for that bowl

guttersnipe.definition: A small poster, suitable for a curbstone
a person of low moral character

guttifer.definition: A plant that exudes gum or resin

guttiform.definition: Drop-shaped, as a spot of color

guttle.definition: To put into the gut; to swallow greedily; to gorge; to gormandize

guttural.definition: Of or pertaining to the throat; formed in the throat; relating to, or characteristic of, a sound formed in the throat
A sound formed in the throat; esp., a sound formed by the aid of the back of the tongue, much retracted, and the soft palate; also, a letter representing such a sound

gutturalism.definition: The quality of being guttural; as, the gutturalism of A [in the 16th cent.]

gutturalize.definition: To speak gutturally; to give a guttural sound to

gutturize.definition: To make in the throat; to gutturalize

gutturo-.definition: A combining form denoting relation to the throat; as, gutturo-nasal, having both a guttural and a nasal character; gutturo-palatal

gutwort.definition: A plant, Globularia Alypum, a violent purgative, found in Africa

guy.definition: A rope, chain, or rod attached to anything to steady it; as: a rope to steady or guide an object which is being hoisted or lowered; a rope which holds in place the end of a boom, spar, or yard in a ship; a chain or wire rope connecting a suspension bridge with the land on either side to prevent lateral swaying; a rod or rope attached to the top of a structure, as of a derrick, and extending obliquely to the ground, where it is fastened
To steady or guide with a guy
A grotesque effigy, like that of Guy Fawkes, dressed up in England on the fifth of November, the day of the Gunpowder Plot
A person of queer looks or dress
A man or young man; a fellow; -- usually contrasted with gals or girls as, it was fun for both the guys and gals; the guys were watching football while the girls played bridge
A member of a group of either sex, usually a friend or comrade; -- usually used in the pl.; as, tell the guys to come inside; are any of you guys interested in a game of tennis?
To fool; to baffle; to make (a person) an object of ridicule

guyanese.definition: of or pertaining to Guyana; as, Jonestown the Guyanese capital
Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Guyana; as, Guyanese followers of the religious cult leader died in Jonestown
A native or inhabitant of Guyana

guze.definition: A roundlet of tincture sanguine, which is blazoned without mention of the tincture

guzzle.definition: To swallow liquor greedily; to drink much or frequently
To swallow much or often; to swallow with immoderate gust; to drink greedily or continually; as, one who guzzles beer

gwiniad.definition: A fish (Coregonus ferus) of North Wales and Northern Europe, allied to the lake whitefish; -- called also powan, and schelly

gybe.definition: To shift from one side of a vessel to the other; -- said of the boom of a fore-and-aft sail when the vessel is steered off the wind until the sail fills on the opposite side

gyle.definition: Fermented wort used for making vinegar

gymnadeniopsis.definition: A genus of North American terrestrial orchids usually included in the genus Habenaria

gymnasiarch.definition: An Athenian officer who superintended the gymnasia, and provided the oil and other necessaries at his own expense

gymnasium.definition: A place or building where athletic exercises are performed; a school for gymnastics
A school for the higher branches of literature and science; a preparatory school for the university; -- used esp. of German schools of this kind

gymnast.definition: One who teaches or practices gymnastic exercises; the manager of a gymnasium; an athlete

gymnastic.definition: Pertaining to athletic exercises intended for health, defense, or diversion; -- originally said of games or exercises, as running, leaping, wrestling, throwing the discus, the javelin, etc.; in modern times more specifically applied to athletic exercises demonstrating balance and agility, such as tumbling, somersaulting, and bodily maneuvers performed on special equipment such as parallel bars or a balance beam; as, gymnastic exercises, contests, etc
pertaining to disciplinary exercises for the intellect

gymnastics.definition: Athletic or disciplinary exercises; the art of performing gymnastic exercises
Disciplinary exercises for the intellect or character
Feats demonstrating a quick mental agility; as, mental gymnastics, verbal gymnastics

gymnoblastea.definition: The Athecata; -- so called because the medusoid buds are not inclosed in a capsule

gymnoblastic.definition: Of or pertaining to the Gymnoblastea

gymnocarpous.definition: Naked-fruited, the fruit either smooth or not adherent to the perianth

gymnochroa.definition: A division of Hydroidea including the hydra. See Hydra

gymnocladus.definition: A genus of leguminous plants; the Kentucky coffee tree. The leaves are cathartic, and the seeds a substitute for coffee

gymnocopa.definition: A group of transparent, free-swimming Annelida, having setæ only in the cephalic appendages

gymnocyte.definition: A cytode without a proper cell wall, but with a nucleus

gymnocytode.definition: A cytode without either a cell wall or a nucleus

gymnodont.definition: One of a group of plectognath fishes (Gymnodontes), having the teeth and jaws consolidated into one or two bony plates, on each jaw, as the diodonts and tetradonts. See Bur fish, Globefish, Diodon

gymnogen.definition: One of a class of plants, so called by Lindley, because the ovules are fertilized by direct contact of the pollen. Same as Gymnosperm

gymnoglossa.definition: A division of gastropods in which the odontophore is without teeth

gymnolaema.definition: An order of Bryozoa, having no epistome

gymnonoti.definition: The order of fishes which includes the Gymnotus or electrical eel.  The dorsal fin is wanting

gymnopaedic.definition: Having young that are naked when hatched; psilopædic;  -- said of certain birds

gymnophiona.definition: An order of Amphibia, having a long, annulated, snakelike body. See Ophiomorpha

gymnophthalmata.definition: A group of acalephs, including the naked-eyed medusæ; the hydromedusæ. Most of them are known to be the free-swimming progeny (gonophores) of hydroids

gymnoplast.definition: A cell or mass of protoplasm devoid of an envelope, as a white blood corpuscle

gymnorhinal.definition: Having unfeathered nostrils, as certain birds

gymnosomata.definition: One of the orders of Pteropoda.  They have no shell

gymnosophist.definition: One of a sect of philosophers, said to have been found in India by Alexander the Great, who went almost naked, denied themselves the use of flesh, renounced bodily pleasures, and employed themselves in the contemplation of nature

gymnosperm.definition: A plant that bears naked seeds (i. e., seeds not inclosed in an ovary), as the common pine and hemlock.  Cf. Angiosperm

gymnospermous.definition: Having naked seeds, or seeds not inclosed in a capsule or other vessel

gymnotus.definition: A genus of South American fresh-water fishes, including the Gymnotus electricus, or electric eel.  It has a greenish, eel-like body, and is possessed of electric power

gynaeceum.definition: That part of a large house, among the ancients, exclusively appropriated to women

gynaecological.definition: Of or pertaining to gynecology; same as gynecological

gynaecology.definition: The branch of medicine that deals with the diseases and hygiene of women; same as gynecology

gynaecophore.definition: A ventral canal or groove, in which the males of some diœcious trematodes carry the female. See Illust. of Hæmatozoa

gynander.definition: A plant having the stamens inserted in the pistil

gynandria.definition: A class of plants in the Linnæan system, whose stamens grow out of, or are united with, the pistil

gynandrian.definition: Having stamens inserted in the pistil; belonging to the class Gynandria

gynandromorphism.definition: An abnormal condition of certain animals, in which one side has the external characters of the male, and the other those of the female

gynantherous.definition: Pertaining to an abnormal condition of the flower, in which the stamens are converted into pistils

gynecocracy.definition: Government by a woman, female power; gyneocracy

gynecology.definition: The science which treats of the structure and diseases of women

gyneolatry.definition: The adoration or worship of woman

gynephobia.definition: Hatred of women; repugnance to the society of women

gynobase.definition: A dilated base or receptacle, supporting a multilocular ovary

gynobasic.definition: Pertaining to, or having, a gynobase

gynodioecious.definition: Diœcious, but having some hermaphrodite or perfect flowers on an individual plant which bears mostly pistillate flowers

gynoecium.definition: The pistils of a flower, taken collectively. See Illust. of Carpophore

gynophore.definition: The pedicel raising the pistil or ovary above the stamens, as in the passion flower
One of the branches bearing the female gonophores, in certain Siphonophora

gyp.definition: A college servant; -- so called in Cambridge, England; at Oxford called a scout

gypseous.definition: Resembling or containing gypsum; partaking of the qualities of gypsum

gypsography.definition: The act or art of engraving on gypsum

gypsoplast.definition: A cast taken in plaster of Paris, or in white lime

gypsum.definition: A mineral consisting of the hydrous sulphate of lime (calcium). When calcined, it forms plaster of Paris.  Selenite is a transparent, crystalline variety; alabaster, a fine, white, massive variety

gypsy.definition: One of a vagabond race, whose tribes, coming originally from India, entered Europe in the 14th or 15th century, and are now scattered over Turkey, Russia, Hungary, Spain, England, etc., living by theft, fortune telling, horsejockeying, tinkering, etc.  Cf. Bohemian, Romany
The language used by the gypsies
Pertaining to, or suitable for, gypsies
To play the gypsy; to picnic in the woods

gypsy moth.definition: A tussock moth (Lymantria dispar or Porthetria dispar or Ocneria dispar) native of the Old World, but accidentally introduced into eastern Massachusetts about 1869, where its caterpillars have done great damage to fruit, shade, and forest trees of many kinds. The male gypsy moth is yellowish brown, the female white, and larger than the male. In both sexes the wings are marked by dark lines and a dark lunule. The caterpillars, when full-grown, have a grayish mottled appearance, with blue tubercles on the anterior and red tubercles on the posterior part of the body, all giving rise to long yellow and black hairs. They usually pupate in July and the moth appears in August. The eggs are laid on tree trunks, rocks, etc., and hatch in the spring

gypsyism.definition: The arts and practices or habits of gypsies; deception; cheating; flattery

gypsyweed.definition: A common hairy European perennial (Veronica officinalis) with pale blue or lilac flowers in axillary racemes

gypsywort.definition: A labiate plant (the Lycopus Europæus). Gypsies are said to stain their skin with its juice

gyracanthus.definition: A genus of fossil fishes, found in Devonian and carboniferous strata;  -- so named from their round, sculptured spines

gyral.definition: Moving in a circular path or way; whirling; gyratory
Pertaining to a gyrus, or convolution

gyrate.definition: Winding or coiled round; curved into a circle; taking a circular course
To revolve round a central point; to move spirally about an axis, as a tornado; to revolve

gyration.definition: The act of turning or whirling, as around a fixed center; a circular or spiral motion; motion about an axis; rotation; revolution
One of the whorls of a spiral univalve shell

gyratory.definition: Moving in a circle, or spirally; revolving; whirling around

gyre.definition: A circular motion, or a circle described by a moving body; a turn or revolution; a circuit

gyrencephala.definition: The higher orders of Mammalia, in which the cerebrum is convoluted

gyrfalcon.definition: One of several species and varieties of large Arctic falcons, esp. Falco rusticolus and the white species Falco Islandicus, both of which are circumpolar.  The black and the gray are varieties of the former.  See Illust. of Accipiter

gyro-pigeon.definition: A flying object simulating a pigeon in flight, when projected from a spring trap. It is used as a flying target in shooting matches

gyrodus.definition: A genus of extinct oölitic fishes, having rounded teeth in several rows adapted for crushing

gyrogonite.definition: The petrified fruit of the Chara hispida, a species of stonewort.  See Stonewort

gyroidal.definition: Having the planes arranged spirally, so that they incline all to the right (or left) of a vertical line; -- said of certain hemihedral forms
Turning the plane of polarization circularly or spirally to the right or left

gyrolepis.definition: A genus of ganoid fishes, found in strata of the new red sandstone, and the lias bone beds

gyromancy.definition: A kind of divination performed by drawing a ring or circle, and walking in or around it

gyron.definition: A subordinary of triangular form having one of its angles at the fess point and the opposite side at the edge of the escutcheon.  When there is only one gyron on the shield it is bounded by two lines drawn from the fess point, one horizontally to the dexter side, and one to the dexter chief corner

gyronny.definition: Covered with gyrons, or divided so as to form several gyrons; -- said of an escutcheon

gyroscope.definition: A rotating wheel, mounted in a ring or rings, for illustrating the dynamics of rotating bodies, the composition of rotations, etc. It was devised by Professor W. R. Johnson, in 1832, by whom it was called the rotascope

A form of the above apparatus, invented by M. Foucault, mounted so delicately as to render visible the rotation of the earth, through the tendency of the rotating wheel to preserve a constant plane of rotation, independently of the earth's motion

gyroscopic.definition: Pertaining to the gyroscope; resembling the motion of the gyroscope

gyrose.definition: Turned round like a crook, or bent to and fro

gyrostat.definition: A modification of the gyroscope, consisting essentially of a fly wheel fixed inside a rigid case to which is attached a thin flange of metal for supporting the instrument. It is used in studying the dynamics of rotating bodies

gyrostatic.definition: Of or pertaining to the gyrostat or to gyrostatics

gyrostatics.definition: The doctrine or theory of the gyrostat, or of the phenomena of rotating bodies

gyrus.definition: A convoluted ridge between grooves; a convolution; as, the gyri of the brain; the gyri of brain coral.  See Brain

gyte.definition: Delirious; senselessly extravagant; as, the man is clean gyte

gyve.definition: A shackle; especially, one to confine the legs; a fetter
To fetter; to shackle; to chain
